dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...I mean, it's not just about, like, profits, right? This Harvard Business Review study found effectively identifying your goals accounts for sixty percent of your overall success in deal closures.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...I mean, it's not just about, like, profits, right? This Harvard Business Review study found effectively identifying your goals accounts for sixty percent of your overall success in deal closures.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effectively identifying your goals and objectives is seemingly a simple step but many experts suggest it accounts for 50% of your success.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sixty percent? Come on. So just thinking about your goals means you're mostly there? That just sounds like, um, confirmation bias.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sixty percent? Come on. So just thinking about your goals means you're mostly there? That just sounds like, um, confirmation bias.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, no, it's about effectively identifying them, uh, and considering your whole environment, cultural perceptions, that kind of thing. Not just, like, direct gains.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, no, it's about effectively identifying them, uh, and considering your whole environment, cultural perceptions, that kind of thing. Not just, like, direct gains.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These are imperative, but equally vital are your business and life environment as well as the cultural perceptions and expectations of the people around you.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Cultural perceptions." So, uh, I need to be an anthropologist just to close a deal now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Cultural perceptions. So, uh, I need to be an anthropologist just to close a deal now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just, like, part of the bigger picture, you know? And then, um, information gathering is huge. The 5W method â€“ who, what, when, where, why, how.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just, like, part of the bigger picture, you know? And then, um, information gathering is huge. The 5W method - who, what, when, where, why, how.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thus, it is important to prepare well by collecting and analyzing information using a classic MBA formula for business background research and problem solving: 5W or 5W1H (who, what, when, where, why and how).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The "5W method." Sounds like something they teach in elementary school, B. Like, obviously you need information. Is that really a groundbreaking insight?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The 5W method. Sounds like something they teach in elementary school, B. Like, obviously you need information. Is that really a groundbreaking insight?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's how you structure it! Eighty-five percent of Fortune 500 companies, uh, attribute successful negotiations to it, according to a global survey.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's how you structure it! Eighty-five percent of Fortune five hundred companies, uh, attribute successful negotiations to it, according to a global survey.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Modern Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) provide great tools for information gathering including general business data in databanks and information about counterparts on LinkedIn, Facebook, etc.).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Eighty-five percent of Fortune 500s say that? That feels a bit, uh, convenient. Like, they're just saying what sounds smart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Eighty-five percent of Fortune 500s say that? That feels a bit, uh, convenient. Like, they're just saying what sounds smart.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a proven method! And then, like, you gotta do a SWOT analysis. One for you, one for the other side. Experts say, uh, seventy-two hours before.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a proven method! And then, like, you gotta do a S W O T analysis. One for you, one for the other side. Experts say, uh, seventy-two hours before.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is especially useful if you run one SWOT assessing your own position, and run the second SWOT for understanding the strengths and weaknesses of the other side of the table.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A SWOT for both sides? So I'm supposed to perfectly predict their strengths and weaknesses? That's, um, a lot of homework for every single meeting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A S W O T for both sides? So I'm supposed to perfectly predict their strengths and weaknesses? That's, um, a lot of homework for every single meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's, it's to develop your strategy, A! And then, uh, pre-meeting questions. Like, at least ten. The Journal of Applied Negotiation Theory says fifteen questions gets you twelve percent higher deal value.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, it's to develop your strategy, A! And then, uh, pre-meeting questions. Like, at least ten. The Journal of Applied Negotiation Theory says fifteen questions gets you twelve percent higher deal value.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One step is to quickly run through a set of pre-meeting questions (at least 10) and possible options, especially taking into consideration the motivation of an individual or head of a team in the forthcoming meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, so now we're putting a specific percentage on asking questions? Fifteen questions, exactly, for a twelve percent boost? That's, um, oddly precise for something so squishy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, so now we're putting a specific percentage on asking questions? Fifteen questions, exactly, for a twelve percent boost? That's, um, oddly precise for something so squishy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's about preparedness, though! And, uh, thinking about red herrings, what you can offer that doesn't cost you much.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's about preparedness, though! And, uh, thinking about red herrings, what you can offer that doesn't cost you much.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Running the pre-meeting questions and scenarios is especially important so you can identify red herrings to offer (issues that have no value for you but might have value for the other side) and build your defense line and your breaking point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Red herrings." Are we, uh, like, fishing now? This all sounds like a lot of academic theory that, um, just falls apart when you're actually in the room with someone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Red herrings. Are we, uh, like, fishing now? This all sounds like a lot of academic theory that, um, just falls apart when you're actually in the room with someone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But the psychological aspect! Non-verbal communication, like, body language, eye contact, it's fifty-five percent of the impact, A.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the psychological aspect! Non-verbal communication, like, body language, eye contact, it's fifty-five percent of the impact, A.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The psychological dimension of negotiation meetings makes a surprisingly big impact on the negotiation process and outcomes, even though in the business setting we expect to see extremely rational people with rational approaches.

dialogue_turns.text: Fifty-five percent? So, uh, if I just stare hard enough, I win? That's, um, I don't know. Seems like you're overthinking it. Just be prepared and, like, be a decent human, right?
